quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 11: Unit 3 Quiz 6
quiz.subtitle: 3.6: Molecular Geometry: Trigonal Bipyramidal, Octahedral
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Advanced molecular shapes with higher coordination

questions.question: Which molecular geometry is associated with a central atom surrounded by five bonding pairs and zero lone pairs?
questions.explanation: Five electron domains arrange themselves with three in an equatorial plane and two in axial positions to minimize repulsion, forming a trigonal bipyramid.

questions.question: What is the ideal bond angle between the two axial atoms in a trigonal bipyramidal molecule?
questions.explanation: The axial atoms are located at opposite poles of the central atom, creating a straight line with an angle of 180° between them.

questions.question: In an octahedral geometry, such as $SF_6$, what are the bond angles between any two adjacent atoms?
questions.explanation: An octahedron has eight faces and six vertices; all adjacent positions are exactly 90° apart from each other.

questions.question: If a molecule has five electron domains, including one lone pair (e.g., $SF_4$), what is its molecular geometry?
questions.explanation: In a trigonal bipyramidal arrangement, lone pairs occupy equatorial positions first to minimize repulsion. One lone pair results in a 'see-saw' shape.

questions.question: What is the molecular geometry of a molecule with six electron domains, two of which are lone pairs (e.g., $XeF_4$)?
questions.explanation: In an octahedral arrangement, two lone pairs will position themselves 180° apart (axial) to minimize repulsion, leaving the four bonding atoms in a 'square planar' shape.

questions.question: Which of the following molecules exhibits a T-shaped molecular geometry?
questions.explanation: Chlorine trifluoride has five electron domains (3 bonds, 2 lone pairs). The two lone pairs in equatorial positions leave the atoms in a T-shape.

questions.question: In a trigonal bipyramidal electron-group geometry, why do lone pairs prefer equatorial positions over axial positions?
options: Equatorial positions have more space (90° and 120° neighbors) compared to axial positions (three 90° neighbors)
Axial positions are further from the nucleus
The equatorial plane is more electronegative
Equatorial positions have no repulsive forces
questions.explanation: Equatorial positions experience less repulsion because they only have two 90° neighbors, whereas axial positions have three.

questions.question: Which molecule represents a square pyramidal molecular geometry?
questions.explanation: Bromine pentafluoride has six electron domains (5 bonds, 1 lone pair). The atoms form a pyramid with a square base.

questions.question: What is the molecular shape of $XeF_2$?
questions.explanation: Xenon difluoride has five electron domains (2 bonds, 3 lone pairs). All three lone pairs occupy the equatorial positions, leaving the two Fluorine atoms in a linear 180° arrangement.

questions.question: How many atoms are directly bonded to the central atom in an octahedral molecular geometry?
questions.explanation: An octahedral molecular geometry occurs when all six electron domains are bonding pairs.

scoreMessages.90: Masterful! You have a superior grasp of hypervalent geometries.
scoreMessages.70: Great job. You are effectively navigating axial and equatorial positions.
scoreMessages.50: Good effort. Review the specific shapes like See-saw and T-shaped.
scoreMessages.0: Focus on the number of lone pairs in 5- and 6-domain systems.
